title: How to Apply Glaze over Chalk Paint

steps.title: Let your chalk-painted project dry completely.
steps.content: Let your chalk-painted project dry completely. Read the label on your chalk paint to find the recommended drying time. Most manufacturers recommend letting your project dry for at least 24 hours between each coat, but it's a good idea to let your project cure for 3 to 5 days before you apply a glaze. [1] X Research source If you're going for a faded shabby-chic look, you might only want 1 coat of chalk paint. If you want a richer, deeper color, apply at least 2 coats of paint to your project.

steps.title: Rub the surface with sandpaper if you want to give it a distressed look.
steps.content: Rub the surface with sandpaper if you want to give it a distressed look. Are you going for a worn, rough style? Instantly age the look of your project by rubbing a block of 60- to 100-grit (medium-grit) sandpaper over the surface of the chalk-paint. Rub the sandpaper back and forth to remove some of the chalk paint so you can see the original paint or wood underneath. Work your sandpaper over areas that would face everyday wear and tear, like corners, edges, or details that stick out. [2] X Research source If you don't have a sanding block, you can use a piece of sandpaper, but it might be a little tricky to hold. Fold the piece of sandpaper a few times to make it easier to grip.

steps.title: Wipe off the dust with a damp sponge if you distressed the wood.
steps.content: Wipe off the dust with a damp sponge if you distressed the wood. Dip a sponge in cold water and squeeze it to remove the water. Then, wipe it over the entire piece you're glazing. This gets rid of sawdust and paint that you removed when you distressed the project. [3] X Research source If you didn't distress the item, you can skip this step and go straight to sealing or glazing.

steps.title: Brush on a topcoat like polycrylic to seal the chalk paint.
steps.content: Brush on a topcoat like polycrylic to seal the chalk paint. Chalk paint really soaks up glaze, which can make it difficult to wipe away. To give you more control over how much glaze you leave on the project, apply a topcoat like polycrylic, which is a protective sealer. To use it, dip a synthetic paintbrush in topcoat and apply a thin layer to the entire surface. Then, let it dry completely before you actually glaze the project. [4] X Research source Most topcoat products dry to the touch within an hour, although you could wait overnight for the product to dry completely. Polycrylic dries clear so you don't have to worry that it will change the finished look of your project.

steps.title: Shop for a water-based glaze to use over the chalk paint.
steps.content: Shop for a water-based glaze to use over the chalk paint. Chalk paint is water-based, so look for a water-based glaze to get the best finish. You'll have an easier time applying the water-based glaze and it will dry faster than an oil-based glaze. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Buy a dark glaze if you want to give the project a dramatic, antiqued look.
steps.content: Buy a dark glaze if you want to give the project a dramatic, antiqued look. Look for a dark brown, black, or antique glaze if you want to darken the details and shadows on a project. If you see a glaze labeled "antique" this usually means that the glaze is dark enough to age the look of the project. [6] X Research source You can use dark glazes on dark chalk paint to give the project a deep, rustic look or apply dark glaze over light colors so the details really stand out.

steps.title: Get a light-colored glaze for a faded, rustic look.
steps.content: Get a light-colored glaze for a faded, rustic look. Sometimes you want a chalk paint project to look slightly worn and a light glaze is perfect for this. Look for a white or pearl glaze. You can apply it to dark chalk paint if you want to lighten the color or put it over light-colored chalk paint to get a distressed or country look. [7] X Research source Keep in mind that a light-colored glaze on light-colored chalk paint won't bring out the carved details in your project.

steps.title: Open the can of glaze and stir it well with a paint stirrer or chopstick.
steps.content: Open the can of glaze and stir it well with a paint stirrer or chopstick. The pigment in the glaze settles as it's stored, so use a wooden paint stirrer or clean chopstick to stir it for at least 30 seconds. [8] X Research source Some people think that stirring vigorously introduces air bubbles, but that shouldn't be a problem since you'll be wiping off the glaze with a cloth later.

steps.title: Dip a 2 in (5.1 cm) paintbrush into your glaze and brush it onto the project.
steps.content: Dip a 2 in (5.1 cm) paintbrush into your glaze and brush it onto the project. If you don't have a synthetic paintbrush, a small foam brush works fine, too! Try to apply a thin, even layer of the glaze, working the brush in the same direction. Ensure that you work the glaze into carved details and trim work. [9] X Research source Work in small sections so you're not feeling rushed, especially if you're glazing a big project like a dresser or large cabinet. For example, brush glaze over just 1 drawer of a cabinet instead all of them so you're not rushing to work them all at the same time.

steps.title: Wipe the surface with a dry cloth to remove the excess glaze.
steps.content: Wipe the surface with a dry cloth to remove the excess glaze. Take a dry cotton cloth and wipe in the same direction you applied the glaze. Avoid using a paper towel or material that sheds fibers. Rub the cloth lightly over the surface to remove a thin layer of glaze or press firmly and evenly to leave glaze just in the carved details. [10] X Research source Keep in mind that the more you wipe, the more chalk paint you'll see. If you're going for a dark, antiqued look, you might not want to remove very much glaze. To give your project an even appearance, wipe off the glaze in the same direction you applied it.

steps.title: Use a damp cloth to wipe the project if you want to lift more of the glaze.
steps.content: Use a damp cloth to wipe the project if you want to lift more of the glaze. If you applied the glaze with a heavy hand or you just want to take a lot of it off, run a clean cloth under cold water and squeeze it out. Then, wipe the project in the same direction you applied the glaze. [11] X Research source Removing the glaze in the same direction makes the project look more natural and even.

steps.title: Let the glaze dry completely overnight.
steps.content: Let the glaze dry completely overnight. Some glazes are fast-drying while others dry slowly to give you more time to work the product into your project. Read the label to see the recommended drying time for the product you're using. In general, let the glaze dry overnight. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Brush a topcoat of polycrylic to seal your project.
steps.content: Brush a topcoat of polycrylic to seal your project. You've just spent time creating a beautiful project, so protect it from damage! Dip a clean synthetic paintbrush into polycrylic and brush a thin layer onto the entire piece. Then, let it dry completely. [13] X Research source Don't want to seal your work? If you don't think your project will be exposed to wear and tear and you'd like it to keep its matte sheen, you can totally skip sealing it.
